PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Lena Kersten Bacon
Address: Chamberlain, Kan., 330 W. Main St.
Birthplace: Neuchâtel, Switzerland

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1904
Where did you set up housekeeping? At my brothers' at Thrivin, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? In Nebraska, U.S.A.
For how many people did you prepare meals? For four people
How far was it to your nearest store? One mile to Survive
How often could a visit be made to the store? Daily if necessary
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Anything you called for, sugar, beans, rice, cabbage, carrots, nuts, tea, flour, shortening, salt & pepper, etc.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Robin Hood (think)
Am not sure for we bought it at the Thrivin. Bank Store
In what quantities did you buy it? By 100 lb. bag X not sure
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? X
How much did you use graham flour? Not any
Whole wheat flour? Not any
Was flour milled locally? No How far away? X What year? X
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? X
What other grain products did you use? X
Cornmeal? Whole Wheat? From the bin Farina?
Other? X
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No we soaked it and cooked it and ate it whole

Name: Mrs. Lena Kernan
Address: 330 N. Main St., Chambly, Kansas

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1944
Where did you set up housekeeping? At my brother's farm.
Where had you been living before that? In Nebraska, USA.
For how many people did you prepare meals? For four people.
How far was it to your nearest store? About a mile.
How often could a visit be made to the store? Daily.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Everything.
Called for sugar, beans, rice, cabbage, chocolate, tea, coffee, flour, salt, pepper, etc.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Petersen's (Pleasant Hill)
Was flour milled locally? Yes
Was flour milled locally? No
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of flour? $1.50
What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal, whole wheat flour, buckwheat flour, etc.
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? With a hand mill.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? For 5 and 10 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar?

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use?

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy?

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We kept two cows.

Butter? Made our own.

Eggs? We had our own chickens.

Did Fred & Chas Kernan bring 2 cows and 6 chickens from Nbr?

What was the price of butter?

Did you pack eggs for winter? No... We had them fresh all winter.

Did you make butter? Yes

Cheese? Yes

What kind of cheese? Cottage Cheese

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Fresh and smoked meats. Fresh fish caught in Long Lake.

How did you get fresh meat? Home butchered.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat? We salt and sugar cured it.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes

What kinds? Pheasants, chickens, ducks, rabbits, geese, antelope.

For how long? I do not know. In any season.

What part did fish play in the family diet? We ate them when we caught them in the spring and summer.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? In all three ways.

Kinds? Perch, pickerel, and pike, I think not sure.

What kind of tea did you buy? X........................ At what price? X...........

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
I forget. Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes, but not if not, where from? raised our own the first year.
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of: 1904
Potatoes 1904... Cabbage 1905... Carrots 1905... Onions 1905...
Turnips 1905... Beets X...........
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 4-5 lb. bags.
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? In bulk.
What weight? X........... How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? X...

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents, or others)?
We brought dried apples and peaches from Neb. and large bag about 50 lbs.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? X........................
Peas? X........... corn? X........... beans? X........... Saskatoons? X...........
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? X........................
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? X........................
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? We kept it frozen.
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Yes here in hills.
We can rhubarb, strawberries, apples, cherries, peaches, grapes.
To what extent? grapes, peaches, tomatoes, green beans by the bu.
Did you make your own vinegar? No...........................................

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) First a slough seepage into a hole nearby later a well.

How far was this water from your home? About 20 rods.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) Pail or barrel.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. We had a well the first fall 1904. Later a windmill was erected on the section near Grinn.
My memory is blank on these items. It had been 48 yrs since 1904 and I had no idea I would ever need the information for an important task like this.

13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? We bought our soap.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes.

What kind of laundry soap did the grocer handle? X.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Coal and wood.

Where did you get your fuel? Wood from the Sandhills. The coal was shipped in 1904.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) No. I had a wood cook stove shipped in.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) My brothers had a two-burner "Monkey Stove" with a drum oven in the floor pipe.

By whom was your first cook stove made? X.

What year was it purchased? 1904. Price? X.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron and tin.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) I bought my glass and china dishes from the N.C.A. Castle.

When did you first see enamel ware? X.

Aluminum? X.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Not much change from 1904 to 1908
Most things were sold in paper sacks.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

For breakfast Oatmeal, bread and butter & milk & cream.
Dinner Potatoes meat gravy, bread butter and jam & milk.
For Supper fried potatoes, bread butter apple sauce and milk. All winter menu.

There were four of us, ages -29, 23, 21 & 5- in 1904

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada? 1904........ Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

There were four. Their ages 29, 23, 21 and 5 yrs.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details. No.
Not much change from 1947-1948

Foot things were sold in paper sacks.

There were four. Their ages 8, 6, 3, 1

and 5 yrs.

Here you can read almost anything. Without looking on one or two out of twenty pages, I give no dates.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

There was a lack of variety in vegetables and fruits, in 1904 but after that our gardens produced excellent vegetables.

The store carried fresh fruits in season.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

Did not purchase canned foods while in Canada from 1904 to 1908 when I left Canada.

The only local fruit, wild strawberries which we ate fresh and choke cherries, which we preserved during those years.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

My experiences during the four years on my Canadian Homestead is written in a separate manuscript in the possession of Mrs. Charles Kernon, Saskatoon, Sask.

528-3rd Ave., Saskatoon.

Mrs. Charles Kernon placed the Archivo here and wrote of pioneer, mentioned that she had this manuscript asked if we would like to have it in addition to this guest. In reply which she has made a few changes from the original.

I told her we would probably be contacting her later, probably in the fall, as we likely would not be seeing about getting the material in before then. She said she would want to get specific permission from Mr. Kernon before doing so.
There was a lack of variety in vegetables and fruits, but after that our gardens produced excellent vegetables.

We also canned fruit in season.

Did not purchase canned fruits while in Canada from 1904 to 1905.

The only local fruit, wild strawberries, which we preserved during those years.

Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada.

My experiences during the four years I was in Canada.
